children.name: willing to change the way you do sth
flexible
children.definition: willing to change your ideas, plans, or methods according to the situation:linh hoạt, mềm dẻo
examples: ▪ If you’re looking for a job you need to be flexible about where you’re prepared to work.
▪ He said the key to his business success was not forgetting to stay flexible.

children.name: adaptable
children.definition: sb who is adaptabledoesnotgetupsetorannoyedif they have to change the way they do things, and easily gets used tonewsituations:dễ thích nghi
examples: Children are often more adaptable than adults.
I’m not sure Ken’s adaptable enough to take a job abroad.

children.name: to change your plans, decisions, intentions
back out
children.definition: to decide not to do sth that you had said you would do : rút lại (cam kết, lời hứa)
examples: It’s too late to back out now.
After you’ve signed the contract, it will be impossible to back out.
You agreed to come. You can't back out now!
back out of
The government is trying to back out of its commitment to reduce pollution.
They backed outofthe deal the day before they were due to sign the contract.

children.name: change your mind
children.definition: thay đổi quyết định , đổi ý
examples: ▪ No, I’m not going out tonight. I’ve changed my mind.
▪ What if she changes her mind and doesn’t turn up?
change your mind about
▪ If you change your mind about the job, just give me a call.
▪ Barry hadn’t changed his mind about leaving.

children.name: have second thoughts
children.definition: to feellesssure about something that you intended to do, and begin to think that it maynotbe agoodidea:do dự
examples: Couples contemplating divorce often have second thoughts when they realize how it will affect their children.
have second thoughts about
It was obvious that the company was having second thoughts about the whole project.

children.name: get cold feet
children.definition: informaltosuddenlyfeel that you are notbraveenough to do sth that you intended to do:chùn bước
examples: A month before the wedding Rose seemed nervous and anxious, and I wondered if she was getting cold feet.
Some investors got cold feet, and pulled out of the project at the last minute.

children.name: backtrack
children.definition: to change your mind about sth you have publicly promised to do, by saying that you will only do part of it or that you might not do it at all:rút lại lời
examples: ▪ If union leaders start to backtrack now, they’ll lose their supporters.
backtrack on
▪ The President seems to be backtracking on some of his election promises.
▪ There is increased pressure on Congress to backtrack on some of the welfare cuts imposed last year.

children.name: to change your belief or opinion about sth
change your mind
children.definition: to change youropinionabout something or someone:thay đổi quan điểm
examples: ▪ At first the doctor said I was suffering from a virus, but now he’s changed his mind.
▪ Everyone has a right to change their mind.
change your mind about
▪ I’m hoping Dad will change his mind about Louise after he meets her tonight.
▪ I’ve changed my mind about the Riviera. I do like it after all.

children.name: come around
children.definition: / comeroundUK  to change your mind so that yougraduallybegin to agree with sb else’s idea or opinion, especially after they havepersuadedyou that they are right:đổi ý
examples: He’ll come around eventually. He doesn’t have any choice, does he?
My mother stopped speaking to me when I first married Tom, but she’s slowly coming around now.
He'll come roundtomy point of view, given a bit of time.
come around to somebody’s view/way of thinking
We had to talk to Sam for a long time before he came round to our way of thinking.
come around to the idea/view that
A lot of employers are coming around to the idea that older employees have a lot to offer a company.
come around to doing sth
We’re hoping that they’ll eventually come round to accepting our offer.
Do you still dislike your office, or have you come roundtothinkingit's all right?

children.name: revise your opinion U
children.definition: revise your opinion formal to change your opinion because sth has happened that has made you realize that you were wrong before :xem lại cách nhìn
examples: revise your opinion about/of
▪ Mrs Pemberton revised her opinion of her future son-in-law when he was accepted into law school.
▪ Since visiting the refugee camps, I have revised my opinion about immigration quotas.

children.name: change your tune
children.definition: to change your mind about something and talk about it in a very different way from how you did before: thay đổi, “đổi giọng", đổi thái độ
examples: ▪ She used to be a Communist, but she changed her tune when her parents left her all that money.
▪ You’ve changed your tune all of a sudden! Only yesterday you were saying you thought Christmas presents were a waste of money.

children.name: change of heart
children.definition: when you begin to feel differently about sb/sth so that your attitude completely changes:thay đổi thái độ, thay đổi suy nghĩ
examples: It’s hard to explain this apparent change of heart.
have a change of heart
He didn’t want kids at first, but he’s had quite a change of heart.
She was going to sell her house but had a change of heart at the last minute.
change of heart about
We can only hope Congress may have a radical change of heart about welfare benefits.

children.name: recant
children.definition: formal to say publicly or formally that you have changed your mind and stopped believing what you used to believe, especially about religion or politics:công khai rút bỏ
examples: During the Moscow Show Trials in the 1930s, prisoners were forced to publicly recant.
After the Reformation, many Catholics recanted to avoid punishment.

children.name: vacillate
children.definition: to keep changing your mind about what you believe or what you are going to do, especially when you have two choices and you cannot decide which one is best:do dự
examples: ▪ The longer you vacillate the less time you’ll have to do anything worthwhile.
vacillate between
▪ The writer seems to vacillate between approving of Collins’ actions and finding them disgusting.

children.name: fickle
children.definition: sb who is fickle is always changing their mind about the people or things that they like so you cannot depend on them:không kiên định, hay thay đổi
examples: She had been a great star once, but the fickle public now ignored her movies.

children.name: blow hot and cold
children.definition: especially UK, informal if sb blows hot and cold about something, they keep changing their attitude so that sometimes they are eager to do it and at other times they are unwilling:luôn thay đổi ý kiến, lúc này lúc kia
examples: ▪ I can’t tell what he wants - he keeps blowing hot and cold.
▪ In our dealings with the police we have found that they can blow hot and cold. Sometimes they are keen to have media help in solving a crime, other times they are more reluctant.

children.name: unwilling to change the way you do sth
be set in your ways
children.definition: to be unable to change thewayyou do things because you have done them that way for a long time:không gì lay chuyển được
examples: ▪ I’m too old and set in my ways to try living in a foreign country now.

children.name: inflexible
children.definition: not willing to change the way you think or the way you do sth:cứng nhắc
examples: ▪ Although many students adored Albers, others found him inflexible and stifling.
▪ Union negotiators criticized the employers for being too inflexible on the issues of pay and working conditions.

children.name: rigid
children.definition: sb who is rigid will never change their mind about what is right or wrong or about how things should be done:cứng rắn, cúng nhắc
examples: ▪ Our manager was so rigid, he’d never listen to our ideas.
▪ Any major changes were prevented by the rigid conservatism of the Church.
rigid in your ideas/opinions/attitudes etc
▪ Andrew was even more rigid in his attitudes towards child-rearing than his father, who was himself quite strict.

children.name: unwilling to accept changes or new ideas
have fixed ideas
children.definition: sb who has fixed ideas has opinions and attitudes that never change, and often seem unreasonable:cố chấp
examples: ▪ These old teachers tend to have very fixed ideas.
have fixed ideas about
▪ He has very fixed ideas about the way a wife should behave.

children.name: reactionary
children.definition: disapproving strongly opposed to change, especially social or political change, in a way that you think is unreasonable:phản động
examples: The seventy-year-old president has been condemned as reactionary by his radical opponents.
He is known for his reactionary views on immigration and the reintroduction of the death penalty.
Cultural attitudes to women were more reactionary than in most of Western Europe.
reactionary[C]phản động
a bunch of right wing reactionaries

children.name: entrenched
children.definition: entrenched attitudes are ones that people have had for a long time and are very difficult to change:bám chặt, cố thủ
examples: entrenched in
▪ The unequal treatment of men and women in the labour market is deeply entrenched in our culture.
firmly/deeply entrenched
▪ In the small towns racial prejudice was deeply entrenched.
entrenched attitudes/habits/beliefs etc
▪ The attitudes of adults to the mentally handicapped tend to be firmly entrenched, and difficult to change.

children.name: stick in the mud
children.definition: informal sb who has old-fashioned attitudes and is unwilling to change or try sth new: kẻcổ hủ, lạc hậu
examples: Come on, don’t be such an old stick in the mud.
She accused him of being a stick in the mud.

children.name: diehard
children.definition: sb who still refuses to change their beliefs even when most other people have changed them:cứng đầu, ngoan cố
examples: ▪ Apart from a few union diehards most of the men have accepted the new productivity agreement.
diehard[adj]
▪ Diehard opponents of the scheme say that they will appeal against the court’s decision.
▪ The attempted coup was staged by a group of the ex-president’s most diehard supporters.

children.name: hidebound
children.definition: a group of people or an institution that is hidebound has very old-fashioned ideas and attitudes and is unwilling to change them:bảo thủ
examples: It was predictable that the medical establishment, so hidebound and reactionary, would reject Dr Stone’s ideas.
The hidebound attitudes of Russia’s powerful aristocracy made any kind of progress impossible.

children.name: when sth that has been decided cannot be changed
final
children.definition: a decision that is final cannot be changed, especially because it has been made officially by sb in authority:quyết định cuối cùng
examples: ▪ They thought carefully before making a final commitment to buy.
final approval/decision etcquyết định cuối cùng
▪ The judges’ decision is final.
▪ The officials have final authority when making decisions.
and that’s final!spoken used to say that you will not change your mind about something, and do not want to hear any more about itThế là hết!/ Chấm hết!
▪ You’re not going out, and that’s final!
have the final saybe the person who makes the final decisionlà người có tiếng nói quyết định
▪ My boss has approved the project, but it’s the Chief Executive who has the final say.
finally[adv] B1
▪ The new school timetable has not been finally decided yet.

children.name: irrevocable
children.definition: formal a decision or choice which is irrevocable cannot be changed after it has been made:không thể thu hồi
examples: Her decision was immediate and irrevocable.
I posted the letter, then realized that what I had done was irrevocable, and that I couldn’t change my mind now.
irrevocably[adv]không thể hủy bỏ, không thể thay đổi
Britain could be irrevocably tied to a single European currency.

children.name: there is no going back
children.definition: use this to say that what you have decided or done is permanent and cannot be changed:không có đường lui.
examples: ▪ You’ve committed your time and money to the project now -- there’s no going back.
▪ It had started as a casual affair but they both knew that now there was no going back.
